A novelty catalyst synthesis method is introduced in this investigation, which employs O3 pulse to induce a segregation of Pd-Pt species to synthesize Pt-Pd core shell structural catalyst. In Pt-Pd alloy, O3 releases highly active oxygen (O*) species (O3→O2 + O·), which combine with Pd species or Pt species selectively. This combination induces a relative migration between Pd and Pt atoms, forming Pt-core@PdO-shell structural catalyst, which meets the thermodynamic stability of Pt-Pd alloy. Core shell structural catalyst displays a better catalytic performance for C-H bond activation. Experimental results indicate core-shell structural catalyst produces more highly active oxygen species than alloy catalyst does. These highly active oxygen species activate C-H bond in alkanes, contributing to a higher catalytic reactivity. In addition, the interaction between Pt-core and PdO-shell lowers the binding energy of ionic Pd species, which facilitates the release of reactive oxygen species. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Core-shell structure Pt-Pd bimetallic catalyst C-H bond activation Oxygen titration Segregation 1 Introduction C-H bond activation has drawn a lot of attentions worldwide. Due to its high binding energy and low polarity, it is both thermodynamic and kinetic challenges to activate C-H bond and form other chemicals. For the low concentration of alkanes, catalytic oxidation is an effective way to remove those hydrocarbons from the exit gas. Noble metal catalysts have been widely concerned by the scholars due to their high activity, such as Pd, Pt, Au, Ag, Rh, etc [1]. For most transition metals, the C-H bond in methane should be activated at high temperatures. In Pd-based catalysts, two stable active phases are observed: Pd and PdO, which could co-exist in reaction conditions [2–4]. In catalytic oxidation reaction, oxidation state plays an important role in catalytic performance. Experimental evidence shows that PdO is more active in C-H bond activation in alkanes [5]. Pd species in metallic state display lower catalytic activity than that in oxidation state. Several metals (Fe, Co, Sn) could inhibit the sintering of the active PdO phase, and improve the thermal stability of PdO [6]. Researches find that the strong combination between water and PdO could prevent the activation of C-H bond [7]. Some scholars have studied the beneficial effect by adding a small amount of platinum in palladium-based catalyst to improve its stability in the presence of water [8–10]. Compared with similar samples prepared by traditional wet impregnation, this catalyst has a better reactivity of oxygen exchange [11]. For methane oxidation over the PdO catalyst, the dissociation of CH4 on Pd-* /PdO site pair (CH4 + Pd−O + Pd-* → Pd−OH + Pd−CH3) is usually considered as the rate-determining step [12,13]. Following this step, the recombination of surface hydroxyls yields H2O and the surface vacancy (2 Pd − OH → H2O + Pd− O + Pd-*) [14]. Considering the promotion of Ni species to Pd-based catalyst, some scholars design the core-shell NiO@PdO/Al2O3 catalyst, which display an excellent performance on C-H bond activation. NiO@PdO/Al2O3 catalyst, with Ni/Pd molar ratio of 2/1, display a high CH4 conversion rate, ~99% [15,16]. As to the platinum catalyst, methane conversion is shown to be independent of methane concentration. While for the palladium-based catalysts, a correlation of conversion vs methane partial pressure is observed [17]. Hydrothermal aging of the platinum catalyst results in a relatively high and permanent losses in methane conversion, while palladium-based catalysts show resistance to deactivation [18]. With additional palladium loading to platinum-based catalysts, it displays an overall improvement in catalytic performance [19]. In addition, platinum catalysts, containing organic compounds and nanoparticles, are also effective catalysts for methane conversion [20–22]. Recent years, there are many researches reporting the catalytic characteristics of Pd and Pt species for C-H bond activation, especially in their structures, chemical valence, coordination number, etc [23,24]. In this paper, we put forwards a novelty catalyst synthesis method, which employs highly active oxygen titration (O3 pulse), to extract active Pd species to nanoparticle surface, and finally forms core-shell structural Pt-Pd catalyst [25,26]. More surface active oxygen are generated over these active sites and activates C-H bond in methane or ethane during catalytic reaction, contributing to a higher catalytic performance [27,28]. This research provides an optional structure for catalyst design, and point out a direction to build a more active catalyst surface. 2 Experiment 2.1 Catalyst preparation This paper, it uses impregnation method to synthesize supported monometallic Pd, monometallic Pt and bimetallic Pt-Pd catalysts. The carrier is Al2O3 powder (Sigma, 220 m2/g surface area, 1.35 cm3/g pore volume). Before preparation, Al2O3 powder is calcined at 850 ℃ in air to remove adsorbed water and surface hydroxyl. Pd (Pd(NO3)2, Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) and Pt (Pt(NH3)4(NO3)2, Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) precursors are titrated on supporter surface, and grinded evenly. Pd mass loading is 1 wt.%, and Pt is 1.83 wt.%. Pd:Pt atomic ratio is 1:1 for bimetallic catalyst. All the catalysts are dried in 100 ℃ for 12 h in oven, and then treated in a calcination system in flowing air (Linde, 99.999%, 0.5 cm3/(g ∙ s)) for 5 h. The calcination temperature is shown in Table 1. After calcination, it employs chemisorption system to evaluate the dispersion and cluster diameter for Pt-Pd alloy catalyst. H2 reduction (Linde, 5 vol% in Ar balance, 0.5 cm3/(g ∙ s), 2 h) is carried out at the temperature displayed in Table 1. Chemisorption experiment uses O2 as probe molecules at room temperature to obtain a monolayer adsorption on cluster surface. Catalyst loading in the chemisorption system is 0.5 g. Before further treatment, all the catalysts should go through calcination and reduction procedures. Particle diameter is calculated via both chemisorption result and TEM result. Their results have errors, but lower than 10%. Then the reduced sample is used to do O3 titration to make core shell structure. As a comparison, part of alloy sample, without O3 titration, is directly used in the catalytic oxidation. This paper put forwards a novel method to synthesize core-shell structural Pt-Pd catalyst. Catalysts are loaded to a pulse reactor that could be vacuumed by a pump. Fig. S1 shows O3 pulse system diagram for synthesis of Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalyst. Computer controls the open and close of solenoid valve (valve 1, valve 2, valve 3) to release O3 pulse to the reactor. Vacuum pump and Mass spectrometer runs all the time, to analyze and evacuate the residual gas in the reactor. The details is shown in Supplementary Information. 2.2 Measurement of catalytic performance Catalytic reactivity of methane and ethane are evaluated in a fixed bed reactor. Because of exothermic properties of oxidation reactions, the catalysts are diluted to avoid the temperature fluctuation. The dilution ratio is shown in Supplementary Information, see Table S1. Catalyst bed, in a flow reactor (30 mm diameter), contains 10 g diluted catalyst sample, with a heating rate of 2 ℃/min. Gas flow are metered by electronic mass flowmeter to achieve a space velocity of 1.2 × 103 cm3/(gcat ∙ h). There is no accumulation or stagnation in the fixed bed. Temperature is measured by a K type thermocouple placed in the center of the reactor. Catalytic conversion can be expressed as: (1) conversion = F in − F out F in F in is the inlet molar flow of methane or ethane, which is controlled by a mass flow meter. F out is outlet molar flow of reactants, which is controlled by a chromatograph analyzer (GC, Agilent 7820 A). Carbon species are fully oxidized, without partial oxidation product. 2.3 Characterization Pt-Pd catalyst surface morphology is observed via HAADF-STEM (High-Angle Annular Dark Field). The contrast image of Pd/Pt species can be obtained directly by high angle ring detector. The transmission electron microscope (120 kV, Hitachi, HT 7800) could recognize bimetallic Pt-Pd catalyst particles, and distinguish Pd and Pt element through the dark field images. Pt element number is higher than Pd element number, showing a bright field. While for Pd element species, it displays a dark field. In addition, the infrared spectrum experiment is carried out on the Thermal Nicolet 6400 FTIR equipment. X-ray Photoelectron Spectroscopy (XPS) is employed to analyze the chemical environment of Pt-Pd bimetallic catalysts. Pt-Pd samples, core-shell or alloy, are analyzed in a hemispherical electron analyzer using Al Kα radiation (500 W) that is monochromatized. All the XPS spectra are calibrated by C 1 s peak (284.4 eV) to correct any charging effects. The spin−orbit-splitting is constrained to a certain extent, and chemical composition is adjusted as a doublet. Valence band spectra are acquired by Al Kα radiation in system with a hemispherical electron analyzer. Peak deconvolution is performed via a XPS Peak-fit 5.0 software for all spectra to identify metallic or ionic Pt-Pd species, which is according to center location and full widths at half height (FWHH). Temperature program reduction, (Micromeritics, AutoChem Ⅱ 2920), is carried out in a fixed bed reactor. Diameter of the reactor is 8 mm and the volume is ~10 mL. The feed gas, 10 vol% H2 in Ar, is introduced into the reactor at flow rate of 50 mL/min. Temperature rise up from room temperature to 900 ℃ at heating rate of 2 ℃/min. Outlet gas is directly fed into TCD detector to measure the consumption of hydrogen species. The finally result is calculated by internal standard method. The XAS spectra of bimetallic Pt-Pd catalysts are collected at Pd K edge (24350 eV) and Pt L3 edge (11564 eV) at the XDS beamline. The experiments are carried out at room temperature via three Argon filled ionization cell. XAS spectra are acquired in the range from 24100 eV to 25300 eV, with a step of 2 eV and 2 s/point. Pd and Pt foil are used as a standard to calibrate energy. EXAFS signals are extracted, and then made Fourier transformation via Kaiser-Bessel window. Structural parameters are fitted by using phase shifts and scattering amplitudes calculated by FEFF for Pt-Pd NPs in face centered cubic (fcc) phases. Cowley short range parameters, depicting homogeneity and short range order, are calculated from the EXAFS results for bimetallic Pt-Pd catalysts. Cowley parameter, α, is defined as follows: (2) α = 1 − CN AB / CN AM x B Where x B is the molar concentration of B atoms in bimetallic sample, CN AB is partial coordination number of A atom, CN AM is the total coordination number of A atom. All coordination numbers are calculated from EXAFS analysis by Pd or Pt absorption edge. x B is acquired by EDS measurement. The final result is regarded as an indicative for heterogeneous or segregated structures. The detailed interpretation of Cowley parameter can be found in Frenkel’s research [29,30]. 3 Result and discussion This paper provides a novelty catalyst synthesis method that employs highly active oxygen titration to drive Pt and Pd species migration, to achieve Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalyst. By means of chemisorption system, HAADF-STEM, TPR, XAS and XPS method, experiments describe the grain type, particle size, element distribution, segregation and bulk/surface structures of Pd/Pt particles. Catalytic performance of alkanes, such as methane and ethane, are evaluated in a fix bed reactor. 3.1 Pt-Pd catalysts evolution via O 3 titration The STEM pictures in Fig. 1 (a, b, c) display the particle morphology of Pd-Pt catalyst. Particles that are randomly chosen in a region, are approximately to be a circle to measure the particle diameter. All catalysts have been calcined and reduced before, but are not treated by oxygen titration (not core shell). It can be seen that monometallic Pt catalyst displays a large amount of small particles, while monometallic Pd catalyst has a lot of large particles. Regarding the catalytic performance of unit mass catalyst, we need some representative parameters, such as the mean value of particle diameter, indices of crystal face, coordination number, etc. [31] Their distribution and composition are displayed in Fig. S2 and Fig. S3. Fig. 1 (d, e, f) show the particle size distribution of monometallic Pd, Pt catalyst and bimetallic Pt-Pd catalyst. The statistics of catalyst particles are conducted in a certain region, which 200 particles are randomly chosen. The average particle diameter is calculated by arithmetic mean value of these 200 particle diameters. There is high similarity between the average particle diameter measured by electron microscopy (6.01 nm, 11.0 nm, 8.9 nm, respectively) and by chemisorption method (6.63 nm, 12.3 nm, 10.1 nm, respectively). The error is within 10%. Our basic thought to acquire core shell structure is to establish an unsaturated oxidative environment over catalyst surface, to induce the Pd-Pt segregation. Fig. 2 shows the schematic of O3 induced Pt-Pd species segregation. O3 is not directly introduced to alloy surface as gas flow, but injected to Pt-Pd catalyst as pulses. O3 pulses generate a small amount of adsorbed oxygen on particle surface, which is highly active to migrate in the clusters. In process of oxygen migration, the small amount of oxygen atoms display a selectivity to combine with Pd or Pt species. This combination contributes to the difference of free energy, which drives the relative migration between Pd and Pt species. O3 pulse method is carried out in a differential reactor, see Fig. S1. After thermodynamic adsorption equilibrium (20 min), Valve 4 open, and the residual gas are evacuated by a vacuum pump. O3 pulse is regulated by a computer system that controls the open and close of magnetic valves. Each pulse is controlled at about 0.5 μmol gas molecule, and the interval is 2 h. Vacuum pump and MS runs all the times. After the pulse flow through catalyst surface, the residual gas, non-adsorbed gas molecules, are evacuated by vacuum pump. Figs. 3a and b show the O/M atomic ratio as a function of O3 pulse for monometallic Pd, Pt and bimetallic catalysts. “RT” indicates room temperature, and “HT” indicates 700 ℃. O3 probe molecules dissociate on active sites, forming single-layer adsorption. However, in high temperature, chemisorption needs more pulse to achieve saturation adsorption [32]. Oxygen adsorption curve at high temperature is higher than that at low temperature, which is due to the bulk oxidation that requires more oxygen atoms. As to monometallic Pt catalyst, the O/Pt atom ratio increases from 0.17 to 0.25. While monometallic Pd catalyst, the O/Pd atomic ratio changes from 0.09 to 0.9. At high temperature, O/Pd atomic ratio is close to 0.9, which indicates that oxygen atoms diffuse uniformly in Pd particles, and O/Pd element ratios in particle could achieve one-to-one, forming PdO species. Fig. 3b shows the O/M atomic ratio as a function of O3 pulse for bimetallic Pt-Pd catalyst. It can be seen that the atomic ratio of O/M at room temperature (0.11) is lower than that at high temperature (0.56). This value (0.11) is lower than O/Pt ratio of monometallic Pt sample (0.17), but higher than O/Pd ratio of monometallic Pd sample (0.09). At high temperature, the ratio of O/M is 0.56, which is slightly higher than 0.5. This means that Pd species is almost completely oxidized, while only a small amount of Pt species could to be oxidized. Oxygen species mainly adsorbs and combines with surface Pt species [33]. Fig. 4 show the differences of HAADF-STEM image for core shell structural particle (with O3 treatment) and alloy particle (without O3 treatment). HAADF-STEM (high angle circular dark field) technique is employed herein to recognize Pd and Pt species. HAADF-STEM detects high angle scattered electrons, or elastic scattered electrons. For bimetallic catalyst, due to the high atomic number of metal Pt, bright region represents Pt species, while Pd species disperse in the region that is not bright. Figs. 4a and b show typical HAADF-STEM images of Pt-Pd core-shell structural particles (newly prepared by O3 treatment). These particles have been distinguished to outer PdO shell (between purple and yellow lines) and inner Pt core (inside yellow circle). Fig. 4 c shows the newly prepared Pt-Pd alloy particle without O3 treatment. It can be seen that Pt-Pd segregation is not notable. The segregation only occurs at the edge of the alloy. The measured lattice spacing of alloy is 2.25 angstroms (111 crystal surface), which is roughly the same as the lattice spacing of single Pd cluster or single Pt cluster (111 crystal surface). Table 2 shows the parameters of surface free energy and bulk free energy of Pd, Pt and their oxides. By comparing the free energy of bulk phase, it can be seen that PdO has the lowest free energy [34,35]. Compared with the surface free energy, the surface free energy of PdO is still the lowest. Generally, there is a relative migration between two elements in the process of crystal formation. The thermodynamic instability between the binary metals would generates a driving force, which forces the whole alloy system to reach a thermodynamic stability. Compared with Pd (100) and Pt (100) crystal surface (as shown in Table 2), the surface free energy of Pt is 2.48 J/m2, which is higher than that of Pd, 1.90 J/m2. After oxidation, the surface free energy of PdO further decreases to 0.53 J/m2. To maintain the stability of Pt-Pd binary metal particle, Pd species will migrate to particle surface as PdO, to reduce the free energy of the bimetal system [36,37]. Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalyst is also proved by EDS technology. Fig. 5 shows the morphological structure and elemental analysis for representative Pt-Pd core shell structural particles. The scanning area is marked in the red box, and the direction is horizontal. The figure nearby the EDS image displays the correlation of distance vs signal intensity. From EDS result, it can be concluded that Pt species in the center is higher than Pd species. While at the shell, it mainly composed of Pd species. In the meantime, we calculate the ratio of Pd/(Pd+Pt) and Pt/(Pd+Pt), indicating that the shell is mainly composed of Pd species (Pd/(Pd+Pt) = 93–96 wt%), but the core is composed of mixture of Pd and Pt species (Pt/(Pd+Pt) = 72–74 wt%). 3.2 Catalytic activity for Pt-Pd catalysts Figs. 6a and b describes the catalytic performance of methane and ethane over monometallic Pd, monometallic Pt, and their bimetallic catalyst. Compared with the catalytic performance of monometallic Pd and Pt samples, Pd is highly active than Pt in methane oxidation. While in ethane oxidation, Pt displays a better reactivity than Pd. For both methane and ethane reaction, alloy catalyst shows the highest reactivity compared with monometallic Pd and monometallic Pt catalyst [38]. The experiments are carried out in oxygen-rich condition. Surface chemisorbed oxygen play an important role for alkane oxidation. In alloy particles, the coupling effect among Pt and Pd species increases the amount of highly active oxygen on surface, contributing to a higher reactivity. [39,40]. To compare the catalytic performance and stability of alloy and core shell catalyst, we perform two experiments: Reaction conversion vs temperature ( Fig. 7a) and Reaction conversion vs Reaction time (Fig. 7b). Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalyst displays better catalytic performance than Pd-Pt alloy catalyst for both methane and ethane reactions. The reason herein is due to the reaction intermediates, highly active oxygen species, which benefit C-H bond activation. Core shell structural catalyst provides more active oxygen species on particle surface. The evidence of active oxygen species is shown in TPR and XPS results. Fig. 7b shows the stability of alloy catalyst and core shell catalyst during alkane oxidation. All of these experiments are conducted for 100 h at 300 ℃. Reactivity of methane oxidation over alloy catalyst presents an obvious decrease. While for other catalysts, it displays a good stability for catalytic performance. In the following XAS experiment, we conduct the measurement for both alloy catalyst and core shell catalyst. To demonstrate whether there exists the structural variation of the fresh and used catalyst, we select the catalyst that has been used for 100 h for comparison. 3.3 Characteristics of core-shell structural catalyst after reaction Catalyst structure is dynamic and can respond to catalytic conditions. In many cases, researchers synthesize catalyst in one condition, but carry out catalytic reactions in another chemical environment. Variation of chemical environment may incur structural changes due to differences of atomic interaction [41,42]. Therefore, we believe chemical environment for catalyst synthesis should be similar with the environment in which we performs catalytic reactions. In this research, both methane and ethane oxidation are carried out in oxygen-rich condition. And catalyst synthesis is treated in oxidative environment, O3 pulse, in which nanoparticles can be oxidized to a large extent. In order to demonstrate the variation of Pt-Pd core shell structure before and after catalytic reaction, we employ TEM, EDS and EXAFS to show their structure after reaction. Both core shell structural catalyst and alloy catalyst are carried out methane and ethane oxidation for 100 h, see Fig. 7b. After the stability test, catalysts that are carried out methane oxidation are chosen to do the TEM, EDS and EXAFS measurement. Fig. 8a and b show the representative TEM and EDS image for core shell structural Pt-Pd catalyst. It can be seen that large nanoparticles exhibit the typical core-shell structure, especially in EDS image. Fig. 8c and d present raw k-space data for Pd/Pt bulk and their bimetallic samples, along with their Fourier transforms displayed in Fig. 8e and f. From visual examination, Pd and Pt EXAFS have some similar properties. Pd EXAFS in Pt-Pd core-shell or Pt-Pd alloy resemble bulk Pd EXAFS data. The difference is EXAFS amplitude that bulk sample has the largest amplitude, and then is core shell structural sample. Alloy sample display the lowest amplitude. While as to Pt EXAFS in Pt-Pd core-shell or Pt-Pd alloy, it can be seen that EXAFS amplitude in core shell structural sample is lower than that of Pd EXAFS data, see Fig. 8e and f. EXAFS amplitude is universally affected by disorder, coordination number, etc. Alloy catalyst presents lowest amplitude due to random distribution of Pd/Pt atoms. While for core-shell structural catalysts, if the metal species of inner core and outer shell are segregated completely, which inner core is composed of pure Pt species, and outer shell is composed of pure Pd atoms, their EXAFS amplitude would be higher than that of alloy sample. However, it can be seen from Fig. 8b and Fig. 5 that the shell of nanoparticle is mainly composed of Pd species (Pd/(Pd+Pt) = 93–96 wt%), but the core is composed of mixture of Pd and Pt species (Pt/(Pd+Pt) = 72–74 wt%). As a result, FT magnitude of core shell catalyst is close to that of alloy sample, see Fig. 8f. To elucidate the structural parameters extracted from EXAFS, experimental data have been plotted in continuous lines to do the fitting. Pd-O scattering and Pt-O scattering are also introduced to do a better fitting for Fourier transforms (FT) at short distances. The fitting procedure of Pt L3 and Pd K edge are done with constraint of distances on heterometallic bonds: R Pd-Pt = R Pt-Pd . The number of free parameters are lower than 33.3% of the number of independent data. Table 3 shows the results of Coordination number (CN), Distance (R), First nearest neighbor disorder parameters ( σ 2 ), and Cowley Parameter. It can be seen in Table 3 that both coordination number and distance of Pt-Pd core-shell catalyst change little before and after catalytic reaction, indicating that the Pd or Pt nearest neighbors do not alter in reaction conditions. And regarding the alloy sample, both coordination number and distance change much, indicating a different structure for bimetallic catalysts. To elucidate the segregated structures, Cowley short range parameter is calculated by total and partial coordination number, and composition, see Equation (2). Average composition is determined by EDS method. Cowley short range parameter is regarded as an objective measurement of segregation structures or degree of randomness. It can be seen that an obvious difference of Cowley parameter between core-shell structural sample and alloy sample are shown in Table 3. Low Cowley parameter value indicates that the metal atoms are randomly distributed in the nanoparticles. While core shell structural sample, no matter before or after reaction, show the high Cowley parameter value, which is in consistent with the reference [29]. Fig. 9 displays H2 TPR result for monometallic Pd, monometallic Pt, Pt-Pd alloy and Pt-Pd core-shell catalysts. H2 reduction describes oxygen storage capacity of these Pt-Pd catalysts. It can be seen that, compared with monometallic Pd catalyst, monometallic Pt catalyst is reduced at higher temperature. H2 reduction peak of Pd catalyst locates at around 250 ℃. For Pt-Pd alloy catalyst, two reduction peaks are shown: the big one locates at around 200 ℃, and the small one appears at around 450 ℃. For Pt-Pd core-shell catalyst, temperature of large reduction peak continuously decreases, to around 170 ℃. The decrease of reduction temperature indicates oxygen species are more active and easier to participate catalytic reaction. In addition, reduction peak areas among these catalysts are sorted in the following order: Pt-Pd core-shell > Pt-Pd alloy > monometallic Pd > monometallic Pt. Pt-Pd core shell structural catalyst can provide more active oxygen species, presenting a higher catalytic reactivity. To understand the binding strength between metal and oxygen species, XPS spectra are introduced herein to analyze the variation of binding energy. Fig. 10 show XPS spectra results for Pt-Pd alloy and Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalysts, respectively. In figure a, there are 0.6 eV and 0.4 eV variation of Pd 3d XPS spectra for Pt-Pd alloy and Pt-Pd core-shell catalysts, indicating the decreases of Pd binding energy. In figure b, it also displays a decrease of Pt binding energy that are 0.5 eV and 0.3 eV respectively. The decrease of binding energy reflects that binding strength of metal to oxygen is weakened. Thus, active oxygen species is easier to desorbed from catalyst surface, and participate C-H bond activation. The content of ionic Pd species in core-shell structure catalyst is higher than that of alloy catalyst. Since the total amount of Pd species are constant, more ionic Pd indicates more oxygen species combine with Pd species, which is consistent with TPR results. In core-shell structure, the amount of Pt-O bonding is less than that in alloy catalyst. Highly active oxygen titration display a selectivity in the combination of Pd and Pt species with oxygen. Table 4 shows ratio of Pdδ+/Pd0 (Pd 3d) and Ptδ+/Pt0 (Pt 4 f) in Pt-Pd catalysts. Pdδ+/Pd0 ratio increases significantly from 1.6 to 2.2, while Ptδ+/Pt0 ratio decreases from 0.67 to 0.43. Core shell structural catalyst optimize the chemical state of metal species, increasing catalytic performance. Core shell structure is a novelty catalyst design direction, which is widely considered in catalytic reactions. This paper uses the method of titration by highly active oxygen, to induce a segregation in alloy particles. Core shell structure, to some extent, increases the amount of surface active sites of Pd, and improves interaction of the two metal species, which in turn produces more highly active oxygen, to activate C-H bond in alkanes in oxidative reactions. 4 Conclusion This paper put forward a novelty catalyst synthesis method that employs O3 pulse, to synthesize PdO shell@Pt core catalyst. The conclusions are as follow: 1. There exists a segregation between Pd and Pt species due to thermodynamic equilibrium. With highly active oxygen titration, Pd species migrate to outer shell, and Pt species migrate to the inner core, forming PdO-shell@Pt-core structural catalyst. 2. Core shell structural catalyst improves metal dispersion and generates larger crystal plane. Via oxygen induced segregation, it extracts highly active species to catalyst surface, providing more active sites, vacancy and reaction intermediates. 3. Because of the interaction between Pd and Pt species, it facilitates the activation of C-H bond in alkanes, improving the catalytic performance significantly. coredata.dc:description: A novelty catalyst synthesis method is introduced in this investigation, which employs O3 pulse to induce a segregation of Pd-Pt species to synthesize Pt-Pd core shell structural catalyst. In Pt-Pd alloy, O3 releases highly active oxygen (O*) species (O3→O2 + O·), which combine with Pd species or Pt species selectively. This combination induces a relative migration between Pd and Pt atoms, forming Pt-core@PdO-shell structural catalyst, which meets the thermodynamic stability of Pt-Pd alloy. Core shell structural catalyst displays a better catalytic performance for C-H bond activation. Experimental results indicate core-shell structural catalyst produces more highly active oxygen species than alloy catalyst does. These highly active oxygen species activate C-H bond in alkanes, contributing to a higher catalytic reactivity. In addition, the interaction between Pt-core and PdO-shell lowers the binding energy of ionic Pd species, which facilitates the release of reactive oxygen species.
coredata.dc:title: O3 titration for synthesis of Pt-Pd core-shell structural catalyst and its catalytic performance on C-H bond activation
